Award.AwardTitle: The International Commission on Stratigraphy: developing global geostandards through international collaboration and consensus
Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Commission on Stratigraphy: developing global geostandards through international collaboration and consensus

EAR-1347494

Stanley Finney, California State University

ABSTRACT
PI requests three years of funding to support the activities of the International Commission on Stratigraphy (ICS), the largest and oldest constituent scientific body of the International Union of Geological Sciences (IUGS). The primary objective of ICS is to standardize the International Chronostratigraphic Chart, which is the basis for the Geologic Time Scale and serves as the global language for expressing geologic time. The funding requested would allow ICS to greatly increase its activities to include 1) field investigations and field business meetings necessary for the selection of Global Stratotype Sections and Points (GSSPs) that define the units of the International Chronostratigraphic Chart; 2) rejuvenation of websites of ICS subcommissions in order that the websites become the primary archives and portals for stratigraphic information produced by the subcommissions; and 3) travel support for young scientists and scientists from under-developed countries to participate in field investigations, field business meetings, and international symposia of the subcommissions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Commission on Stratigraphy (ICS) defines of the units of the Geologic Time Scale, which is the common global language for discussing the history of Earth and life upon it.  The only record of Earth's history and the only basis for establishing a time scale are successions of sedimentary rocks that make up a signficant part of the Earth crust.  These rocks include fossils, as well as chemical, magnetic, and lithologic evidence, on which to interpret Earth's history and to recogize the passage of time.  Defining the units of the Geologic Time Scale requires the investigation of successions of sedimentary rocks worldwide and, for it to be accepted as a global standard, requires consensus of stratigraphic specialists worldwide.  Hundreds of stratigraphers worldwide must be involved for both field investigations and to arrive at decisions on standards by consensus.  The support from the National Science Foundation to the International Commission on Stratigraphy allowed for the travel of specialists from more than 20 countries to locations in North America, Asia, Europe, and Africa in order for them to gather data in the field and to hold business meetings at which decisions were made.  Furthermore, it supported the participation of students, young scientists and scientist from underrepresented countries.  The work of the Commission of Stratigraphy is long-term. The three-years of support from NSF augmented by 50% the supprot received by ICS form the International Union of Geological Sciences.  Thus, it resulted in a marked increase in the study of important successions of sedimentary strata and in the international disucssions necessary to arrive at decisions on global standards.
